Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
rtc - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Screen.title: RTC Process
Screen.Label: Residual Time Correction Process
Non-surface consistent trim statics process for 2D
MAX_STATIC=
NUM_WIN=
FOLD_MAX=
REPLACE=
HDR_CC=
CC_MIN=

Help.Tip: Maximum static shift, in ms, for individual traces within a CMP.
Help.Text:
rtc - MAX_STATIC
Maximum static shift, in ms, for individual traces within a CMP.
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = real > 0
 MAX_STATIC cannot be less than MSCTFB.

Help.Tip: Number of windows on a trace.
Help.Text:
rtc - NUM_WIN
Number of windows on a trace.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = integer > 0
 If there is only one window on a trace, the trace will be statically shifted.
 If there are two or more windows, the trace will be dynamically shifted
 such that the center of each window will be shifted based on the correlation
 of that window with the base trace.

Help.Tip: Maximum fold for any input CMP gather.
Help.Text:
rtc - FOLD_MAX
Maximum fold for any input CMP gather.
 
 Default = 200
 Allowed = int > 0
 If a CMP is input with greater fold than FOLD_MAX, RTC will delete the excess
 traces.

Help.Tip: Replace the stacked trace with the base trace?
Help.Text:
rtc - REPLACE
Replace the stacked trace with the base trace?
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 Whether to replace the stacked trace with the corresponding base trace for
 forming subsequent base traces?
 (This has no effect if the base traces are being read from a file.)

Help.Tip: Header word used to store the trace's correlation coefficient.
Help.Text:
rtc - HDR_CC
Header word used to store the trace's correlation coefficient.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0 - NWIH
 HDR_CC is the header word used to store the trace's maximum correlation
 coefficient.
 If HDR_CC = 0, then do not store the correlation coefficient.

Help.Tip: Minimum correlation coefficient allowed for a trace window.
Help.Text:
rtc - CC_MIN
Minimum correlation coefficient allowed for a trace window.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = 1.0 > real >= 0.0
 If the correlation for a window does not exceed CC_MIN, that window will be
 shifted by the average static found from all windows in the trace not failing
 this test.  More details in General Description.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_STAT using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
rtc - SELECT_PATH_STAT
Choose PATH_STAT using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Write an RTC static file to this pathname.
Help.Text:
rtc - PATH_STAT
Write an RTC static file to this pathname.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = char
 This can be a very large file.  Its use is not recommended since RTC can be
 rerun at little cost.
 
 If PATH_STAT = NONE, then do not write the RTC static file.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_STAT.
Help.Text:
rtc - PATH_STAT_INFO
Status of PATH_STAT.

Help.Tip: Lowest frequency to use for computing correlations.
Help.Text:
rtc - FREQ_BEG
Lowest frequency to use for computing correlations.
 
 Default = 5
 Allowed = real > 0
 
 Bandpass filter is applied only to the base trace being correlated with.
 Output traces are not bandpass filtered.

Help.Tip: Highest frequency to use for computing correlations.
Help.Text:
rtc - FREQ_END
Highest frequency to use for computing correlations.
 
 Default = 0.5*Nyquist
 Allowed = FREQ_BEG < real < Nyquist
 
 Bandpass filter is applied only to the base trace being correlated with.
 Output traces are not bandpass filtered.

Help.Tip: Method for building the base trace.
Help.Text:
rtc - METHOD
Method for building the base trace.
 
 Default = CORR
 Allowed = CORR  (Correlate and shift stacked trace windows to form base)
 Allowed = SDIP  (Do semblance-based dip stack to form base)
 Allowed = FILE  (Use base traces from TROT file specified by PATH_BASE_IN)
 Allowed = FILE_THEN_CORR  (Use base traces from TROT file, then CORR method)
 Allowed = FILE_THEN_SDIP  (Use base traces from TROT file, then SDIP method)
 
 For the IMS process:
   Method FILE is NOT an allowed option.
   For method FILE_THEN_CORR, the base traces from the TROT file are used
    for the first iteration, and method CORR is used to create base traces for
    the rest of the iterations.
   For method FILE_THEN_SDIP, the base traces from the TROT file are used
    for the first iteration, and method SDIP is used to create base traces for
    the rest of the iterations.
 
 For the RTC process:
   Methods FILE_THEN_CORR and FILE_THEN_SDIP are NOT allowed options.

Help.Tip: Maximum Shift in the Central Trace used to Form the Base.
Help.Text:
rtc - MSCTFB
Maximum Shift in the Central Trace used to Form the Base.
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 Maximum Shift, in ms, in the Central Trace used to Form the Base.
 MSCTFB cannot exceed MAX_STATIC.
 Used for METHOD = CORR and FILE_THEN_CORR only.

Help.Tip: Length of the semblance window in seconds.
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN_LEN
Length of the semblance window in seconds.
 
 Default = 0.1
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 Used for METHOD = SDIP and FILE_THEN_SDIP only.

Help.Tip: Header word designating CMP X grid coordinates.
Help.Text:
rtc - HDR_X
Header word designating CMP X grid coordinates.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = 1 - NWIH

Help.Tip: Header word designating CMP Y grid coordinates.
Help.Text:
rtc - HDR_Y
Header word designating CMP Y grid coordinates.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = 1 - NWIH

Help.Tip: Value of header word HDR_X for the center of any CMP.
Help.Text:
rtc - X_INIT
Value of header word HDR_X for the center of any CMP.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Value of header word HDR_Y for the center of any CMP.
Help.Text:
rtc - Y_INIT
Value of header word HDR_Y for the center of any CMP.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real
 
 For 2D data, this number is normally irrelevant.

Help.Tip: Increment of header word HDR_X between CMPs (X grid bin width).
Help.Text:
rtc - X_INC
Increment of header word HDR_X between CMPs (X grid bin width).
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Increment of header word HDR_Y between CMPs (Y grid bin width).
Help.Text:
rtc - Y_INC
Increment of header word HDR_Y between CMPs (Y grid bin width).
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 For 2D data, this number is normally irrelevant.

Help.Tip: Number of CMPs to stack in the X grid direction to form base.
Help.Text:
rtc - BINS_X
Number of CMPs to stack in the X grid direction to form base.
 
 Default = 5
 Allowed = odd int > 0

Help.Tip: Number of CMPs to stack in the Y grid direction to form base.
Help.Text:
rtc - BINS_Y
Number of CMPs to stack in the Y grid direction to form base.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = odd int > 0
 
 For 2D data, this number should be zero.

Help.Tip: Number of CMPs to leave as a gap in the X grid direction.
Help.Text:
rtc - GAP_X
Number of CMPs to leave as a gap in the X grid direction.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0 or odd int > 0
 
 Number of CMPs in the X grid direction to leave as a gap in the center of
  the group of CMPs used for the base trace.
 GAP_X must be less than BINS_X.
 Not used if METHOD = FILE.

Help.Tip: Number of CMPs to leave as a gap in the Y grid direction.
Help.Text:
rtc - GAP_Y
Number of CMPs to leave as a gap in the Y grid direction.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0 or odd int > 0
 
 Number of CMPs in the Y grid direction to leave as a gap in the center of
  the group of CMPs used for the base trace.
 GAP_Y must be less than BINS_Y.
 Not used if METHOD = FILE.
 For 2D data, this number should be zero.

Help.Tip: Maximum dip in X grid direction for traces used to form the base.
Help.Text:
rtc - DIP_X
Maximum dip in X grid direction for traces used to form the base.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 Maximum dip in X grid direction, in ms/trace, for traces used to form the
 base.  Non-zero values allow larger shifts for more distant traces and can
 help compensate for dips.
 Not used if METHOD = FILE.

Help.Tip: Maximum dip in Y grid direction for traces used to form the base.
Help.Text:
rtc - DIP_Y
Maximum dip in Y grid direction for traces used to form the base.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 
 Maximum dip in Y grid direction, in ms/trace, for traces used to form the
 base.  Non-zero values allow larger shifts for more distant traces and can
 help compensate for dips.
 Not used if METHOD = FILE.
 For 2D data, this number should be zero.

Help.Tip: Number of CMPs in the X grid direction to use for an initial base.
Help.Text:
rtc - BINS_INIT_X
Number of CMPs in the X grid direction to use for an initial base.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = odd int > 0
 
 BINS_INIT_X must not exceed BINS_X.
 Used for METHOD = CORR and FILE_THEN_CORR only.

Help.Tip: Number CMPs in the Y grid direction to use for an initial base.
Help.Text:
rtc - BINS_INIT_Y
Number CMPs in the Y grid direction to use for an initial base.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = odd int > 0
 
 BINS_INIT_Y must not exceed BINS_Y.
 Used for METHOD = CORR and FILE_THEN_CORR only.
 For 2D data, this number should be one.

Help.Tip: CMP X grid dip increment in milliseconds/trace.
Help.Text:
rtc - DIP_INC_X
CMP X grid dip increment in milliseconds/trace.
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 Used for METHOD = SDIP and FILE_THEN_SDIP only.
 If DIP_X is zero, this number is irrelevant.

Help.Tip: CMP Y grid dip increment in milliseconds/trace.
Help.Text:
rtc - DIP_INC_Y
CMP Y grid dip increment in milliseconds/trace.
 
 Default = 10.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 
 Used for METHOD = SDIP and FILE_THEN_SDIP only.
 If DIP_Y is zero, this number is irrelevant.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_BASE_IN using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
rtc - SELECT_PATH_BASE_IN
Choose PATH_BASE_IN using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Pathname for input TROT file containing base traces.
Help.Text:
rtc - PATH_BASE_IN
Pathname for input TROT file containing base traces.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 Used for METHOD = FILE and FILE_THEN_CORR and FILE_THEN_SDIP only.
 
 For the RTC process:
   If METHOD = FILE, use base traces from the file PATH_BASE_IN.
   Otherwise create base traces using the other specified parameters.
 
 For the IMS process:
   If METHOD = FILE_THEN_CORR or FILE_THEN_SDIP, use this file only for the
    first iteration.
   Otherwise create base traces using the other specified parameters.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_BASE_IN.
Help.Text:
rtc - PATH_BASE_IN_INFO
Status of PATH_BASE_IN.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_BASE_OUT using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
rtc - SELECT_PATH_BASE_OUT
Choose PATH_BASE_OUT using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Pathname for output TROT file containing base traces.
Help.Text:
rtc - PATH_BASE_OUT
Pathname for output TROT file containing base traces.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 
 Base traces are written to the file PATH_BASE_OUT unless the parameter
 PATH_BASE_OUT = NONE.  The base traces are output regardless of the
 specified METHOD (with restrictions specified below).
 
 For the RTC process:
   If METHOD = FILE, base traces are not output because they would be
    identical to the input base traces.
 
 For the IMS process:
   Base traces are written after each iteration, overwriting the previous
    contents of the file.
   If METHOD = FILE_THEN_CORR or FILE_THEN_SDIP, base traces are not output
    after the first iteration because they would be identical to the input
    base traces.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_BASE_OUT.
Help.Text:
rtc - PATH_BASE_OUT_INFO
Status of PATH_BASE_OUT.

Help.Tip: Header word designating window coordinate X.
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN_HDR_X
Header word designating window coordinate X.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = any value from 1 through NWIH.
 
 Header word containing coordinate X to use for specifying spatially varying
 windows.

Help.Tip: Header word designating window coordinate Y.
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN_HDR_Y
Header word designating window coordinate Y.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = any value from 1 through NWIH.
 
 Header word containing coordinate Y to use for specifying spatially varying
 windows.

Help.Tip: Array of coord X values for specifying spatially varying windows.
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN_COOR_X
Array of coord X values for specifying spatially varying windows.
 
 Default = 0.0 (one location).
 Allowed = up to any number of locations specified by WIN_HDR_X values.
 
 If only one X coordinate is specified, its value is irrelevant.

Help.Tip: Array of coord Y values for specifying spatially varying windows.
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN_COOR_Y
Array of coord Y values for specifying spatially varying windows.
 
 Default = 0.0 (one location).
 Allowed = up to any number of locations specified by WIN_HDR_Y values.
 
 If only one Y coordinate is specified, its value is irrelevant.
 For 2D data, only one Y coordinate should be specified.

Help.Tip: Coordinate from WIN_COOR_X array.
Help.Text:
rtc - COOR_X
Coordinate from WIN_COOR_X array.

Help.Tip: Coordinate from WIN_COOR_Y array.
Help.Text:
rtc - COOR_Y
Coordinate from WIN_COOR_Y array.

Help.Tip: Window number.
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN
Window number.

Help.Tip: Array of window top times (in seconds).
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN_TIM_BEG
Array of window top times (in seconds).
 
 Default = top of trace (TSTRT) for one window.
 Default = equally spaced for multiple windows.
 Allowed = any number of values >= top of trace.
 
 These windows are spatially varying as given at the (WIN_COOR_X,WIN_COOR_Y)
 locations.  Each correlation window is interpolated between the specified
 coordinates, and extrapolated unchanged outside of the grid of coordinates.
 
 The number of values specified is the number of windows on a trace times
 the number of window locations.

Help.Tip: Array of window bottom times (in seconds).
Help.Text:
rtc - WIN_TIM_END
Array of window bottom times (in seconds).
 
 Default = bottom of trace (TSTRT+(NDPT-1)*DT) for one window.
 Default = equally spaced for multiple windows.
 Allowed = any number of values > WIN_TIM_BEG and <= bottom of trace.
 
 These windows are spatially varying as given at the (WIN_COOR_X,WIN_COOR_Y)
 locations.  Each correlation window is interpolated between the specified
 coordinates, and extrapolated unchanged outside of the grid of coordinates.
 
 The number of values specified is the number of windows on a trace times
 the number of window locations.

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
rtc - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
rtc - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
rtc - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
rtc - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
rtc - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
rtc - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
rtc - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
rtc - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
rtc - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
rtc - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
rtc - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : RTC         (Residual Time Correction)
 Category   : statics
 Written    : 1989-02-21   by: Tom Stoeckley and Greg Lazear
 Revised    : 2006-10-16   by: D. Glover
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Non-surface consistent trim statics process for 2D.
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : No
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 RTC shifts each trace in a CMP according to its correlation with a base
 trace.  If only one correlation window is specified, the shift is a static
 shift.  If two or more windows are specified per trace, each window is
 correlated with the base trace separately and the shift is a dynamic
 (time-varying) shift.  RTC is not surface consistent.
 
 
 2D and 3D Processing
 
 RTC can be used with 2D data or certain swaths from a 3D survey.  For 3D
 processing, RTC3D is recommended.
 
 
 Minimum Correlation Coefficient
 
 Shifts are picked for each window whose correlation exceeds CC_MIN.  If the
 correlation for a window fails this test, that window will be shifted by the
 average static found from all windows on that trace not failing this test.
 If all of the windows on a trace fail the test, the trace is not shifted.  If
 only one window passes the test (or only one window is specified), the trace
 is statically shifted.  Otherwise, the trace is dynamically shifted.
 
 
 Storing Correlation Coefficients
 
 If HDR_CC > 0, the maximum correlation coefficient for a trace is stored in
 this header word.  This header word can then be used later for weighted
 stacks (weighting by correlation coefficient), or for killing traces (using
 process SELECT) with small correlation coefficients.
 
 
 An Historical Note
 
 RTC is related historically to the Cyber processes MTC, RSIC, RSDP and RTC.
 RSIC and RSDP replaced stacked traces with base traces, while MTC did not.
 MTC, RSIC and RSDP employed a static shift, while Cyber RTC (with two or more
 windows) used a dynamic shift.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 RTC is normally used as the last step in a statics solution to remove any
 small non-surface consistent residual static that may be present.
 
 Because RTC is not surface consistent, it can be somewhat unstable and is
 normally used with small values of MAX_STATIC (10 ms or less) to avoid larger
 shifts that might have resulted from wild correlations.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                           REVISION HISTORY
 
     Date        Author     Description
     ----        ------     -----------
028. 2006-10-16  D. Glover  Added NULLIFY statements for Intel compiler.
027. 2006-01-10  B. Menger  Removed Unused Variables.
 26. 2004-01-07  Stoeckley  Fix bug for METHOD=SDIP where traces were treated
                             as dead since HDS(25) was not set.
 25. 2003-06-02  Stoeckley  Fix buffer length sctr(5000) to sctr(obj%ndpt).
 24. 2001-10-18  Stoeckley  Fix print format with field not wide enough.
 23. 2001-08-24  Stoeckley  Add file selection box and file status message.
 22. 2001-02-15  Stoeckley  Change wrapup flag.
 21. 2000-10-20  Stoeckley  Add missing required documentation sections.
 20. 2000-09-27  Stoeckley  Add workaround code near calls to BASETRACE_BUILD
                             and MTH_AMPLITUDE_NORMALIZE to circumvent
                             problems with the Portland Group compiler.
 19. 2000-07-20  Stoeckley  Change INL and CRL parameter names to X and Y;
                             change TEMPFILE back to TEMPTFILE since the
                             improved throughput turned out to be an NFS issue.
 18. 2000-06-21  Stoeckley  Change SHIFT_MAX parameter to MAX_STATIC to be
                             consistent with other statics processes; fix
                             subtle bug which sometimes caused RTC to quit
                             prematurely; replace TEMPTFILE with TEMPFILE to
                             improve throughput by a factor of five.
 17. 2000-06-05  Stoeckley  More changes to be consistent with modifications
                             to the BASETRACE primitive.
 16. 2000-05-18  Stoeckley  Change to be consistent with modifications to
                             the BASETRACE primitive.
 15. 2000-05-01  Stoeckley  Converted from old system.
 14. 1998-12-14  K.Goodger  Begin using the fortran90 compiler.
 13. 1996-11-11  K.Goodger  If detect a zero record number for DTREAD,
                             set N to zero and return.
 12. 1994-04-04  Troutt     Change header array for STRINI of base trace
                             file to a dummy array (HDUM).  It was HDS,
                             which was being used to control flow through
                             the process.
 11. 1993-02-11  Troutt     Increase limit for number of windows from 10 to
                             25 (new parameter NWTMAX).
 10. 1992-08-11  Troutt     Allow UNITS=SHOT. This option uses hwds 37 and
                             38 to be used for varying the data windows.
  9. 1992-02-21  Troutt     Added handling of tail mute header word 64. Add
                             call to MUTEHW.
  8. 1991-07-30  Troutt     Fix call to FILTERG so that BASE array is not
                             overrun.
  7. 1990-12-07  Peterson   Correct error return argument on calls to
                             CALL CLOSFIL (ARG1,ARG2,*error return address).
  6. 1990-10-29  Stoeckley  Fix bug which occurred when first CMP bin is
                             zero.  Also fix STATFILE format to allow
                             larger offsets.
  5. 1989-06-12  Stoeckley  Fix graded windows bug with UNITS=DIST.
  4. 1989-05-30  Stoeckley  Add base trace header word parameters, and
                             correct problems with 2-dimensional forms of
                             TRMIX and ICDPREC.
  3. 1989-05-02  Stoeckley  Added semblance dip option for base trace,
                             plus some other parameter changes.
  2. 1989-04-17  Stoeckley  Added parameters CCHDR and FILE, and removed
                             trace killing.
  1. 1989-02-21  Stoeckley  Original code built from Greg Lazear's MTC.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
